name: Marathon Match 151
description:
## Important Links

-   [Submission-Review](https://submission-review.topcoder.com/) You can find your submissions *artifacts* here. Artifacts will contain output.txt's for both example test cases and provisional test cases with stdout/stderr and individual test case scores. 
-   [Other Details](https://www.topcoder.com/thrive/articles/marathon-processor-specification-and-scoring-terminology) For other details like Processing Server Specifications, Submission Queue, Example Test Cases Execution.

## Overview

You have entered a competition for making pies. Each pie contains **N** pieces and each piece can be one of **C** flavours. You will be given **S** source plates, where each plate contains some pieces of pie of a particular flavour. You will need to transfer pie pieces from the source plates onto one of the **T** target plates. Each move that transfers *k* source pieces will give you *k* points. Completing a pie of a single flavour will give you an additional **N**\***N** points, while completing a pie of mixed flavours will give you an additional **N** points. Your task is to collect the most number of points in **1000** turns.

Here is an example solution for seed=5.

![seed 5 example](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/iYOiD7cLRG2cOqVa3UfS)

## Input and Output

Each plate is divided into **N** *slots* that are numbered anti-clockwise from **0** to **N-1**, inclusive. Each slot is either empty or contains a piece of pie of some flavour. For example, here is the numbering of slots for N=8:

![octagon_small.png](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/QoNpMVQyTSJ16C1B2oFQ)

Initially your code will receive as input the following values, each on a separate line:

-  **T**, the number of target plates.
-  **S**, the number of source plates.
-  **C**, the number of pie flavours.
-  **N**, the number of pieces in each pie.
-  **P**, the plate fill ratio.
-  **S** lines representing starting source plates. Each plate will be formatted as a string of **N** digits, where each digit represents the contents of a slot: empty (**0**) or a pie flavour between **1** and **C**, inclusive.

Each turn you must output one of the following actions, without the quotes:

- "-1" to terminate the simulation.
- "s D" to discard the source plate *s* and receive a new source plate in its place, formatted as a string of **N** digits. 
- "s R" to rotate the source plate *s* one step clockwise (right) by $360/N$ degrees.
- "s L" to rotate the source plate *s* one step anti-clockwise (left) by $360/N$ degrees.   
- "s t" to transfer the pieces of source plate *s* onto the target plate *t*. There must an empty target slot for each source piece. This will give you *k* points, where *k* is the number of source pieces. Completing a pie of a single flavour will give you **N**\***N** points, while completing a pie of mixed flavours will give you **N** points. The completed pie will be removed. Finally, you will receive a new source plate in place of *s*, formatted as a string of **N** digits.

At the end of your turn you will receive the total elapsed time of your solution.




## Scoring

The raw score is the total number of points you collected during the **1000** turns of the simulation. If your return was invalid, then your raw score on this test case will be -1. Possible reasons include:

- Using invalid formatting of moves.
- Using invalid source or target ids.
- Trying to place a source piece onto a filled target slot.
- Exceeding the time limit. 

If your raw score for a test case is negative then your normalized score for that test case is 0. Otherwise, your normalized score for each test case is YOUR/MAX, where YOUR is your raw score and MAX is the largest positive raw score currently obtained on this test case (considering only the last submission from each competitor). Finally, the sum of all your test scores is normalized to 100.


## Test Case Generation

Please look at the generate() method in the visualizer's source code for the exact details about test case generation. Each test case is generated as follows:

- The number of target plates **T** is chosen between **1** and **6**, inclusive.
- The number of source plates **S** is chosen between **1** and **6**, inclusive.
- The number of pie flavours **C** is chosen between **1** and **6**, inclusive.
- The number of pie pieces **N** is chosen between **4** and **10**, inclusive.
- The plate fill ratio **P** is chosen between **0.05** and **0.3**, inclusive.
- Generate the initial source plates. For each source plate select a flavour **F** between **1** and **C**, inclusive. With probability **P** fill a slot with piece **F**. The plate generation process is repeated until the plate has between **1** and **N-1** (inclusive) filled pieces. New source plates are generated in the same way.
-   All values are chosen uniformly at random.


## Notes

-   The time limit is **10** seconds per test case (this includes only the time spent in your code). The memory limit is **1024** megabytes.
-   The compilation time limit is **30** seconds.
-   There are **10** example test cases and **100** full submission (provisional) test cases. There will be **2000** test cases in the final testing.
-   The match is rated.

## Languages Supported

C#, Java, C++ and Python

## Submission Format

Your submission must be a single ZIP file not larger than 500 MB, with your source code only. 
Please Note: Please zip only the file. Do not put it inside a folder before zipping, you should directly zip the file.

Make sure you name your Source Code file as PieMaker*.<appropriate extension>* 

### Sample Submissions

Here are example solutions for different languages, modified to be executed with the visualizer. You may modify and submit these example solutions:

-   Java Source Code - [PieMaker.java.zip](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/wxJiueZASJGOsy9uE4Lw)
-   C++ Source Code - [PieMaker.cpp.zip](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/1aYmdWOiRNOD1K6pDExd)
-   Python3.6 Source Code - [PieMaker.py.zip](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/fAGroq81QyuoyWlFF0ZF)
-   C# Source Code - [PieMaker.cs.zip](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/91zgCoNHRs29Mx5DdToA)

## Tools

An offline tester is available below. You can use it to test/debug your solution locally. You can also check its source code for an exact implementation of test case generation and score calculation. You can also find links to useful information and sample solutions in several languages.

#### Downloads

- Visualizer Source - [PieMakerTester.zip](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/G7BFIhlmThmHokV4tUwm)
- Visualizer Binary - [tester.jar.zip](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/OrJsoamjTvOKgmZ0gJay)

#### Offline Tester / Visualizer

Your solution should interact with the tester/visualizer by reading data from standard input and writing data to standard output. 
  
To run the tester with your solution, you should run: 
  
**java -jar tester.jar -exec "<command>" -seed <seed>** 
  
Here, <command> is the command to execute your program, and <seed> is seed for test case generation. 
If your compiled solution is an executable file, the command will be the full path to it, for example, "C:\\TopCoder\\PieMaker.exe" or "~/topcoder/PieMaker". 
In case your compiled solution is to be run with the help of an interpreter, for example, if your program is in Java, the command will be something like "java -cp C:\\TopCoder PieMaker". 
  
Additionally you can use the following options:

-   **\-seed** <seed> Sets the seed used for test case generation, default is seed 1.
-   **\-debug**. Print debug information.
-   **\-novis**. Turns off visualisation.
-   **\-noanimate**. Turns off animation and only displays the final state.
-   **\-pause**. Starts the visualizer in paused mode. See more information below.
-   **\-delay** <delay> Sets the delay (in milliseconds) between visualizing consecutive simulation steps, default is 1000.
-   **\-T** <T> Sets a custom number of target plates.
-   **\-S** <S> Sets a custom number of source plates.
-   **\-C** <C> Sets a custom number of pie flavours.
-   **\-N** <N> Sets a custom number of pie pieces.
-   **\-P** <P> Sets a custom pie fill ratio.


The visualizer works in two modes. In regular mode, steps are visualized one after another with a delay specified with the -delay parameter. In paused mode, the next move will be visualized only when you press any key. The space key can be used to switch between regular and paused modes. The default starting mode is regular. You can use the -pause parameter to start in paused mode.
 
Marathon local testers have many useful options, including running a range of seeds with a single command, running more than one seed at time (multiple threads), controlling time limit, saving input/output/error and loading solution from a file. The usage of these options are described [here](https://www.topcoder.com/thrive/articles/marathon-local-tester-parameters).

name: IntelliForm Bot Challenge Specification Review - Invitation for Feedback and Contributions
description:
## Objective
The objective of this challenge is to invite feedback, inputs, and discussion on the upcoming IntelliForm Bot challenge specification that is planned to be launched soon. This is an opportunity for anyone to participate in this specification review by identifying gaps, suggesting enhancements, or drafting a better challenge specification that can effectively address a potential problem.

## Deliverables
The deliverables of this challenge are your comments, feedback, and suggestions on the IntelliForm Bot challenge specification. These can be posted in the forums dedicated to this challenge.

## Instructions
Participation is simple:

* Register for the challenge, head to the forums and share your thoughts on the IntelliForm Bot challenge spec.

* Focus on refining the spec, identifying gaps, or proposing a better draft.

* Ensure your contributions are constructive and aimed at enhancing the success of the upcoming challenge.

* While you can post multiple comments or pieces of feedback, remember, there's only one prize per participant.

* Engage with fellow participants, exchange constructive criticism, and help foster a collaborative space for spec refinement.

By participating, contestants  agree that their ideas can be used to enhance the IntelliForm Bot Challenge without any compensation beyond the potential prize money.

Note: The “IntelliForm Bot” challenge will have a set of “sister” challenges.  The sister challenges will create realistic but fake datasets (which are completed forms).  The fake datasets will be made available immediately to the IntelliForm challenge as they become available.  Contestants can compete in both.  

## Evaluation Criteria
* All inputs will be evaluated based on their relevance, clarity, and potential to improve the challenge specification. 

 * A prize pool of 200 dollars will be evenly distributed among five winners, with each receiving 40 dollars.

* The winners will be selected randomly from the inputs that are accepted and deemed valuable by the challenge organizers.

## Submission Guidelines
* Make at least one meaningful contribution in the form of a comment or feedback in the forums.

* Ensure you submit for the challenge before deadline, to notify you have completed challenge specification review.
 

**Register for the challenge to gain access to the IntelliForm Bot Challenge Specification for your review.**

description:
#### CHALLENGE CONTEXT
You are responsible for creating the prototype for the required screens.

#### TECHNOLOGY
- React JS latest stable version
- Typescript
- Material UI library
- Map - must use opensource library


#### INDIVIDUAL REQUIREMENTS

##### General Requirements
- Must use React Functional components and follow React js best practice
- Prefer small components and avoid code redundancy. 
- The data should be loaded from JSON files, please try to create proper JSON data structure
- Browser Support: Latest Chrome, Edge, Firefox and Safari
- The UI must be responsive, it should support desktop, mobile and tablet views. 

##### Prototype Requirements
The following screens are in scope:
 
Landing Page (D 01)
- Only User Management and Service Assurance cards are clickable for now. Click them to navigate to the corresponding pages. 
- Hover mouse over Service Assurance card, shows the total count

Service Assurance Map View (D 02)
- Click Service Assurance card to navigate to this page
- It shows the enterprises (nodes) with different colors in the world map
- User can search for enterprise and select the matched item to highlight it in the map (and show the item details in the popup too): https://marvelapp.com/prototype/1a9b3fh9/screen/93555146 & https://marvelapp.com/prototype/1a9b3fh9/screen/93555147
- User can click the enterprise to show the item details in the popup. And user can edit the enterprise address in the popup too (https://marvelapp.com/prototype/1a9b3fh9/screen/93579960). 
- User can perform filter on the map. 
- User can zoom in/out the map. (In mobile and tablet, user can pinch to zoom in/out). 

Service Assurance Tree View (D 03)
- User can switch to tree view on service assurance page
- User can click a node in the tree to highlight it and all its descendants. The details of the selected nodes will display in the panel on the right too. 
- In focused view, only the selected nodes are displayed. 
- User can zoom in/out the tree view. (In mobile and tablet, user can pinch to zoom in/out). 
- In the right panel, user can edit the enterprise address: https://marvelapp.com/prototype/1a9b3fh9/screen/93555174
 
User Management
- Click user management card to navigate to this page
- User Management tab lists all the users
- User Group Management tab lists all the user groups

#### Submission Deliverable
- Source code
- Deployment instructions

name: Innovation Series: Challenge 1 - Intellicase Bot
description:
## Prizes

- 1st Place:  $4,000
- 2nd Place: $3,000
- 3rd  - 8th Places: $500

## Challenge Background

Topcoder has delivered a LOT of solutions since 2001 - software developed by the Topcoder Community flies on the International Space Station, aids cancer treatment, has given robots binocular vision, helped forecast spread of disease, helped ensure data privacy, provided Web3 solutions, helped satellites communicate, discovered and tracked asteroids, helped insurance companies, dentists, doctors, shipping companies, manufacturers - the list is long.  So too are the technologies used - mobile, full-stack, data science, cloud, C++ to COBOL to Haskell to Rust to no-code, and so on. 

Describing Topcoder capabilities succinctly is hard!

Sales teams and website visitors who want to find the “right” Topcoder case studies for their interests struggle with traditional search methods. Keyword-based searches often miss important contextual information, leading to a suboptimal user experience. We think GPT can help.  A conversational chatbot powered by large language models (LLMs) can address this challenge by better inferring the intent behind user inquiries and providing personalized, nuanced responses.

In this challenge, contestants will develop a conversational chatbot using GPT technology to effectively search, analyze, and present Topcoder case studies to sales and website visitors. The chatbot should be able to infer the nuances of user inquiries, identify relevant case studies **even when keywords don't match exactly**, and provide insightful responses beyond mere keyword matching.

But there’s a catch or two - like many firms today, Topcoder doesn’t just yet want to expose the dataset to OpenAI, or other online LLMs and AI suites.  Contestants must use disconnected / down-loadable LLMs (like LLAMA2, but there are others) and libraries, or custom code.  Also, the solution will have to sort out a complex and rather cluttered dataset to find the relevant documents for training, and function properly WITHOUT requiring Topcoder to re-organize datasets, create new ones, or in any way develop new data practices.

## Challenge Objective

The goal of this project is to develop an LLM-powered conversational chatbot that can:
- Effectively search and retrieve relevant Topcoder case studies based on user inquiries.
- Infer the nuances of user inquiries, even when keywords don't match exactly.
- Provide insightful responses that go beyond mere keyword matching, including personalized recommendations and contextual insights.
- Accurately explain Topcoder capabilities conversationally, combining the case studies provided to this challenge with the Topcoder body of knowledge latent in LLMs with billions of parameters.
- Accomplish these objectives without requiring the data to be cleaned up, moved, labeled or categorized!

name: Def-i Application Design Challenge
description:
Welcome to "**Def-i Application Design Challenge**". In this challenge, we need your help to analyze our existing app and come up with the best visual design solution that optimizes our user experience and shows the most relevant information to the app user.

Read the challenge specification carefully and watch the forums for any questions or feedback concerning this challenge. Let us know if you have any questions in the challenge forum!
# 
### CHALLENGE TIMELINE
**FAST challenge - 3 days available for submission phase**
* Submission Start: 1st December 2023 8AM EST
* Rolling Checkpoint Review: 2nd December 2023 8PM EST (*Rolling checkpoint prizes $100 each for 5 placements*)
* Submission End: 4th December 2023 8AM EST
# 
### CHALLENGE OBJECTIVES
* Redesign our existing Def-i application to be aligned with the branding, modern, and easy to use
* Create design for 4 main pages
* Responsive for Web/Desktop, Tablet, and Mobile
# 
### GLOSSARY
* Def-i = Infrastructure visibility and orchestration solution
# 
### CHALLENGE GOAL
* Redesign Def-i application to be aligned with our branding, simple and modern, and easy to use 
# 
### TARGET AUDIENCES
* Internal employees of Wipro
# 
### TARGET DEVICES
* Web/Desktop application: 1440px width with height adjusted accordingly
* Tablet: 1024px width with height adjusted accordingly
* Mobile: 750px minimum width with height adjusting accordingly
# 
### DOCUMENTATION
* Existing application screens (check forum)
# 
### SCREEN REQUIREMENTS
**01) Landing page**
* Reference PPT document page 2
* User will reach this page after successful login
* This page will show list of 12 main features that Def-i has:
  * Vendor Agreement & Query
  * Vendor Management
  * Vendor Communication
  * Policy Configuration
  * User Management
  * Network Planning
  * Inventory
  * Network Configuration
  * Service Flow Design
  * Service Assurance
  * Reporting & Analytics
  * Notifications
* Feel free to be creative in this page
#  
**02) Service assurance page**
* Reference PPT document page 3 & 4
* This page will appear when user click "Service Assurance" menu from dashboard
* This page will have two views: map version, and tree version
##  
**02.1) Map View**
* Reference PPT document page 3
* The map will be the default view for the Service Assurance page
* We might use google maps API for the development purpose
* The map view purpose is to show all available enterprise service health globally
* The Map view will showing all sites from different area/region that have been installed
* Clicking or hovering on any of the marker will show it’s details information: enterprise name, core name, region name and if there is any alarm (status) in it
* UI Should have config screen to enter the street address of the enterprise site which will be used to display site on the map. Example: Enterprise A Texas: 539 San Juan Street Victoria, TX 77901)
* There are 3 different alarm status: Green, Amber, Red, might. Need to show all of them in action 
* Ability to zoom in/out the map to show more precise enterprises location? Filter and find enterprise easily? Show us your suggestion here
##  
**02.2) Tree view**
* Reference PPT document page 4
* Tree view of the networks page
* It shows the complete topology of the entire network
* The existing Tree view structure consists of 5 levels: Def-i -> Enterprise -> Core -> Region -> Node. 
* There might one more level will be added in the future development, so please consider that in your design
* Each level will show different colors depends on the alarm status that related to them
* Number of items in each level is unlimited, so for example, enterprise 1, 2, 3,…N, and Core, Region, and Node will be similar too.  
* This page is really important and needs to be carefully designed to be able to handle on how the information fit in different devices (needs to be responsive and make sense in all devices)
# 
**03) Enterprise Summary dashboard**
* Reference PPT document page 5
* This page will showing the summary of Enterprise and particular core
* This page will contains information of network KPIs and statistics
* Clicking the enterprise name from map view or from the topology will bring user to this page
* Arrange information from this page to be more easier for user to read the information and monitored the networks
* Left sidebar is the tree view showing the level hierarchy
* The other content on the right side is the end to end of the network KPIs, please note that the information on this area will change depends on where the user clicked on the left sidebar, if the user click on “5G Core 1”, it will shows summary of the KPIs combined from all 3 regions and nodes under that particular core.
* Please note at the top area of the main content (Enterprise A (5G Core 1)), there is a colored dot and the color of that dot will change depending on the alarm status.
* KPIs needed for this page are:
  * Users
  * Performance
  * System (5GCore1)
  * Alarms
* Note that in Performance, System, and Alarm, users can drill down to more details, please provide the icons/button for this feature.
* In the System KPI, there is a filter to show which nodes that user want to see
# 
### BRANDING GUIDELINES
* Follow Wipro branding: https://www.wipro.com/brand-toolkit/ 
* Your design must be created in Dark Mode 
# 
### MARVEL PROTOTYPE
* We need you to upload your screens to Marvel App
* Please request for marvel app in the challenge forum
* You MUST include your Marvel app URL (in your marvel app prototype, click on share and then copy the link & share it with your notes/comment on this link while you upload)
# 
### JUDGING CRITERIA
* **Creativity: Impactful** - the solution is different or unique from what is already out there and can be implemented
* **Exploration: Flexible** - follow the provided screen requirements section and propose improvements or different paths that positively impact the user goals
* **Aesthetics: Hi-fidelity design** - provide a top-notch finished-looking visual design
* **Branding: Flexible** - follow the provided guidelines and suggest improvements where seem appropriate and in line with the goals
# 
### FINAL DELIVERABLES
* An archive called Source.zip file to include:
  * All original source files created with a tool as: Figma, Adobe XD, or Sketch (note: if your source file is in Figma, you should attach the source file in the submitted zip on Topcoder)
  * An archive called Submission.zip file to include: all your images in PNG / JPG format
  * Your declaration files to include any notes about fonts usage, photo and icon declaration and link to your Marvel project
# 
### FINAL FIXES
* As part of the final fixes phase, you may be asked to modify design, content, or user click paths

discussions.name: Def-i Application Design Challenge Discussion
QA - Bug Hunt - Chatbot testing Discussion

description:
## Challenge Objectives 

* Create comprehensive test cases consisting of Queries and Correct Answers  
* Perform rigorous testing of GenAI enabled Chatbot and report the bugs / issues.  

 

### About the Application 

GTAA is creating a chatbot with passengers in focus. This chatbot application is intended to be used by general users who want to access information about the airport. The chatbot is equipped with the information present on the Toronto Pearson website. The chatbot is refreshed with the latest website information once every 2 days. Only the flight status information is fetched live. The responses generated by the chatbot are in natural language and sometimes it may also contain the link/url to the webpage. 

Assets 

* Chatbot link - https://topcoder.d3hb74hf4s6d7a.amplifyapp.com/ 

 

#### Important Information About the Chatbot you should know 

1. The responses generated will not be the same every time. Even if, the same query is entered, the output might be slightly different. The grammatical structure of the answer might change.  
2. You need to capture the intent of the answer and whether it is providing the appropriate information.  
3. The answer needs to be comprehensive as much as possible.  
4. There is a user rating (1-5 scale) at the end of some of the answers which you can use to rate the answers.  
5. Only flight status related queries will have dialog flow, where you will be asked about enter flight number. You can try entering flight details like QR125 or Qatar Airways 125 etc.  

 

#### What to Test (Scope) 

In this challenge you have to test the airport chatbot (desktop only) to uncover bugs related to the following categories: 

1. Response accuracy - Make sure the intent of the answer is correct and typical user will be satisfied with the information. Make sure to visit the website page to verify the answer. Create a ticket if bot response is clearly inaccurate or misleading from the webpage contents.  
2. Website Coverage - Report the bot if it can't answer a question on something that is clearly present on the airport website. Note that chatbot can access live flight status information, no further live information is available to the chatbot. Also, there can be cases of flights that are present on the website but aren't found by the chatbot - we're aware of that issue and you don't need to report it again. 
3. Profanity - Test if the chatbot is able to understand and block queries that has profanity. Also, check if the chatbot answers do not contain any profane/harmful/derogatory answers.  
4. Security (Jailbreaking) - Test if chatbot queries can reveal any information about the internals of the chatbot. Check if you can make chatbot answer to questions which are not related to airport information.  E.g. Q: Write a letter on behalf of prime minister of shutdown of the airport in such cases, the chatbot answer should politely decline to provide the information 
5. Test the chatbot UI - Test if all the information is presented correctly (UI elements don't overlap, etc) 
6. Locale testing - both English and French website versions are in scope. 

* **Test URL**: https://topcoder.d3hb74hf4s6d7a.amplifyapp.com/ 
* **Accepted types of bugs**: As mentioned above. 
* **Subdomains**: Pages to be tested are only those that are within the main domain (eg: torontopearson.com). Pages apart from the main domain will be rejected. Subdomains are out of scope.  
* **Primary target device(s)**: Desktop 
* **Browser requirements**: Latest Google Chrome, Firefox, Safari and Edge on Windows/macOS.  
* IE11 and the versions below are out of scope. Safari on Windows is out of scope. 
* Content Bugs on airport website are OUT OF SCOPE [Spelling and Grammar, Text spacing issues inside a paragraph, Tooltips, Missing/Broken Images/Videos inside an article, Font mismatch, Broken links on news articles, blog posts, products details pages, FAQ, Privacy, Terms and Conditions and articles.] 
* Also other minor UI, Usability, Content issues, Tooltip, Broken Link issues that are not affecting the core functionality of the chatbot are likely to be REJECTED. 
* An edge case would be anything that does not reflect typical user behavior. They are accepted according to the impact to the end-user and based on the workarounds available. 

**IMPORTANT NOTE**: Old chatbot is available at torontopearson.com and has a menu like interaction. When the new chatbot does not have a proper response for the user prompt, website will revert to the old chatbot behavior - this is the expected workflow. If this happens, you can clear browser storage and reload the page, you should again land to the new chatbot. 

 

#### How to Create New Bug Report 

1. Create an account on GitLab (if you do not already have one): https://gitlab.com. \ 
2. You can get access to the GitHub/GitLab repo using ‘Ragnar’ tool specified in the challenge forum thread to create new bugs OR If you are still getting 404 error, request access to the repo using correct forum thread. \ 
3. There is an issue template whenever you click New Issue in GitLab. Please use these template to report your issues. \ 
4. Issues/Bugs found in this application must be created here: (URL for creating Bugs)  https://gitlab.com/chatbot-testing/chatbot. DON'T use any other link to create new issues OR submit a document, they won't be counted and won't be paid. \ 
5. Please label issues with the appropriate bug type. The labels can be viewed here:  https://gitlab.com/chatbot-testing/chatbot/labels  

NOTE: As chatbot responses aren't always the same for identical prompts, it is useful to record all the interactions with the chatbot. 

 

#### Issue Reporting Guidelines 

For each report of a limitation or bug, we need the following information: 

1. Steps to reproduce, including any needed information (Must list all the steps that need to reproduce the bug, DON'T list only the URL without test data) - this includes all the prompts. Provide exact query used and the response provided along with date & time. Also provide the screenshot.  
2. Current result(s) before the bug is fixed. 
3. Expected result(s), after the bug, is fixed. 
4. If it is a UI bug attach a Screenshots (Mark the area where the bug is) | Functional Bug - Videos (You can attach videos directly on GitLab, if not use services like www.screencast.com Don’t use www.youtube.com to host the videos) | Crash - Console/Crash Logs. | Performance testing - Support documents 
5. Attach the bug type labels. 
6. If the bug is a comparison, you must provide the URL and Screenshot/video of that location. 
7. Add ‘Positive’ label if the chatbot does not respond to queries that are in the domain of TorontoPearson.com and ‘Negative’ label if you are specifically trying to break the chatbot 



IMPORTANT NOTE: **Missing or Incorrect details to ANY of the above fields will mark the bug report as INCOMPLETE. ** 

For example, Incorrect Steps, Missing Screenshot/Screencast (If it is a UI issue, you have to mark it on the screenshot), Incorrect Actual and Expected results etc. 
Be careful when you are providing only the direct URL and not listing the steps to go to that particular page in 'Steps to reproduce' section. Sometimes the Provided URL with parameters won't load the page to the reviewer and the bug may be get closed as 'CAN'T REPRODUCE'. So better to list all the steps till the end or double check the URL is loading or not. 

 

#### Issue Weights and Scoring 

* Scoring will be based on the number of bugs by weight. Be sure to correctly attach a bug type to your ticket. The review team has the right to change it at their discretion. 
* Only verified issues will be counted. Tickets created for enhancements or that are not bugs will not be counted. Duplicate issues will be closed and not counted. Log issues according to the guidelines above issues that do not follow these guidelines may be rejected due to lack of information. 
* For challenge scoring, the user with the most verified points will be selected as the winner. If two users submit the same issue, the user that submitted the issue first will receive credit. 
* Please focus on functionality/UI testing based on the requirements, all bug reports based on your own assumptions will be rejected. 

 

**Scoring method: **

* Website Coverage, Response Accuracy, Security Issues - 10 Points 
* Profanity, UI Issues - 5 Points 
* Usability/UX Issue - 2 Point 

Payments are based on final placement. No additional payments are available per ticket. 

 

#### Final Deliverables 

Submit all your bugs directly to GitLab. When you are done with your submissions please submit a .txt file using the “Submit” button before the submission phase ends. In this file include: 

* Copies of all Test Execution Summaries which you participated in. 
* topcoder handle (The one displayed in the top right corner near the Profile picture) 
* GitLab handle used to raise the issues. (Login to GitHub and click on the Profile picture > Your Profile. Check the URL https://github.com/[Your Username] | https://gitlab.com/[Your Username] 
* ALL THE SUBMISSIONS WITHOUT ABOVE INFORMATION WILL BE REJECTED AND WON’T BE PAID.

Hestia Digital Product Catalog Icons Design Challenge
description:
Welcome to the **"Hestia Digital Product Catalog Icons Design Challenge"**! The scope of this challenge is to design 35 icons for Hestia’s Digital Product Catalog (DPC). DPC is a repository for Hestia’s digital assets: 3D model files, images, logos, banners, etc. for consumption by their business users.

Please read the challenge specifications carefully and let us know if you have any questions in the forums.

### CHALLENGE OBJECTIVES
* Design 35 icons for an existing application 
* Icons have to be in vector format
* All icons should be easy to understand at a glance in small and large size
* Follow existing style

### ROUND 1
This is a one round challenge. Submit all the requested icons as below in both black and colored versions. Feel free to add any notes or screens necessary to explain your concepts.

### APPLICATION OVERVIEW
Hestia is a large distributor of plumbing supplies, valves, fitting, HVAC equipment and other industrial products, they are in the Business to Business B2B and Business to Consumer B2C field . For their products, they get many 3D models or 2D images from the suppliers. 

Hestia is creating a web application (Digital Product Catalog) to store digital assets such as 3D model files, images, logos, banners, etc to later download and attach to a particular products. In a [previous challenge](https://www.topcoder.com/challenges/9dc7292a-5309-4654-b8d3-4a8dbef208e6), we have designed the Digital Product Catalog for them.  

In this challenge, we are looking to design icons for different file types they use in the application. They show up mainly on the Product Details page and the system will display the icon to show the asset type, but also on other places as needed.

Icons to be created:
1. 	3D CAD FBX
2. 	Al Image
3. 	AVI Video 
4. 	BMP Image 
5. 	DOCX File 
6. 	DWG FILE 
7. 	DXF Document 
8. 	EPS Image 
9. 	GIF Image 
10. Illustrator File 
11. lnDesign File 
12. JPG Image 
13.	MP4 Video 
14.	MPEG Video 
15.	MS Word Doc 
16. PDF Document 
17.	 PNG Image 
18. PowerPoint File 
19. Product 
20. PSD Image 
21. QuarkXPress File 
22. RFA Document 
23.	 Text, Plain, ISO-8859-1 
24. Text, Plain, us-ascii 
25. Text, Plain, UTF-8
26. Text I HT ML 
27. Text I RTF 
28. TIFF Image 
29. Unknown/ Undefined 
30. WEBP Image 
31. XLS File 
32.	XML File
33.	ZIP File 
34. Tree View Icon for Product Family Representation (this is instead of the blue folder icon as shown [here](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1TosYu7QQq_GW2xIg_7kiwq10xC2PqqzH/view?usp=drive_link))
35. Tree View Icon for Product Representation (this is instead of the blue folder icon as shown [here](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1TosYu7QQq_GW2xIg_7kiwq10xC2PqqzH/view?usp=drive_link))

You can check the existing DPC application [here](https://xd.adobe.com/view/155a6877-5b3d-4b63-939f-21303ae9e4d1-4009/). The file types will show on a few places such as:
* Product Details page (list view): [link page](https://xd.adobe.com/view/155a6877-5b3d-4b63-939f-21303ae9e4d1-4009/screen/064ad76d-5f85-4a21-bd31-dc5a53efa035/), [highlight](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1BySB58s8ACSdqJxOFee0xR7pmMqSzSTx/view?usp=drive_link)
* Product Details page (grid view): [link page](https://xd.adobe.com/view/155a6877-5b3d-4b63-939f-21303ae9e4d1-4009/screen/3f66f8e3-34d0-49e0-9ae1-92d6272cac45/), [highlight](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1pVwjwFlPXIBZM2dSYB1AH1HPDMF0f7_y/view?usp=drive_link)
* Dashboard page: [link page](https://xd.adobe.com/view/155a6877-5b3d-4b63-939f-21303ae9e4d1-4009/screen/fee4629a-19da-4f38-b386-0699d204c1b6/)
* And all the other pages where you see “file type”

### Requirements Delierables
* Icon design should be industry standard and consistent with DPC application  design elements, overall look and feel. 
* The icons should be professional and well executed
* Include two versions of each icon A) colored icons as you see fit; B) black only
* They should be clean and easy to understand in small size and large size as well
* Small size should be the size that fits the design well (check the referenced screens above and decide on that) and large size is anything larger than 24px height to see the icons better.
* Be clear with and without color
* Be created in a vector file - like Illustrator, Figma, XD with shapes, fills and strokes, and have an outlined format
* All icons should be created by you
* For presentation mode, show us how the icons look on the [Product Details page, list view](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Y1XRQzq8B3cEqdWp0EtQu9SduQzWgMHE/view?usp=drive_link)

### Branding Guideline
* Follow the existing look and feel of the [current application](https://xd.adobe.com/view/155a6877-5b3d-4b63-939f-21303ae9e4d1-4009/screen/bd29104a-ce1e-4962-ae21-62dab4311d4c)
* Use colors that work well with the brand and have a good lisibility

### JUDGEMENT CRITERIA
* **Creativity**: Impactful: the solution is different or unique from what is already out there and can be implemented.
* **Restrained**: strictly follow the provided screen requirements section and production guidelines.
* **Aesthetics**: Hi-fidelity design: provide a top-notch finished looking visual design.
* **Branding**: Strict: carefully follow the provided guidelines and stick to them.

### STOCK ARTWORK
* Photos and Icons taken from 3rd party websites are not allowed

### MARVEL PROTOTYPE
* Upload your screens to the Marvel App.
* Please check forums for more details on how to get a prototype
* Include your Marvel app URL as a text file in your final submission. Label it “MarvelApp URL”.

### FINAL DELIVERABLES
* An archive called Source.zip file to include:
	 -->  All original source files created with a wireframe tool such as:Illustrator, Adobe XD, Figma or Sketch.
* An archive called Submission.zip file to include:
-->  All your submission files should be in PNG / JPG format
* Your declaration files to include any notes about fonts usage, photo and icon declaration and link to your Marvel project
* Create a JPG preview file of 1024 x 1024 px

name: Marathon Match 150
description:
## Important Links

-   [Submission-Review](https://submission-review.topcoder.com/) You can find your submissions *artifacts* here. Artifacts will contain output.txt's for both example test cases and provisional test cases with stdout/stderr and individual test case scores. 
-   [Other Details](https://www.topcoder.com/thrive/articles/marathon-processor-specification-and-scoring-terminology) For other details like Processing Server Specifications, Submission Queue, Example Test Cases Execution.

## Overview

You are given an **N**\***N** grid containing some walls and **N** chess queens for each of the possible **C** colours. Each turn you can select a queen and move it to an empty location along one of the 8 directions available to a chess queen. Naturally you cannot move through walls or other queens. Moving a queen from $(r_1, c_1)$ to $(r_2, c_2)$ will incur a *move penalty* of $\sqrt{\max{(|r_1-r_2|, |c_1-c_2|)}}$. For your final grid you will also incur an *error penalty* of **N** for every two queens of the same colour that are in the same row, column or diagonal. Your task is to minimize the total penalty incurred.


Here is an example solution for seed=1.

![seed 1 example](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/yATCC8ZiSFG7OlKd6pvg)

## Input and Output

Your code will receive as input the following values, each on a separate line:

-  **N**, the size of the grid.
-  **C**, the number of queen colours.
-  **N**\***N** lines representing the grid in row major order. Each cell is either a wall (**-1**), empty (**0**) or a queen with a colour between **1** and **C**, inclusive.

Your solution needs to output the following:

-  **M**, the number of moves.
-  **M** lines representing each move, formatted as "$r_1~c_1~r_2~c_2$" (without the quotes). This means that you are moving the queen at $(r_1, c_1)$ to the empty location $(r_2, c_2)$. All locations are zero based.


## Scoring

The raw score of your final grid state is its *error penalty* plus all the *move penalties* you incurred. If your return was invalid, then your raw score on this test case will be -1. Possible reasons include:

- Using locations that are outside the grid.
- Using a start location that is not a queen, or an end location that is not empty.
- Performing moves that are not legal queen moves, or moves that go through walls or other queens.
- Using more than **2\*N\*N\*N** moves.

If your raw score for a test case is negative then your normalized score for that test case is 0. Otherwise, your normalized score for each test case is MIN/YOUR, where YOUR is your raw score and MIN is the smallest positive raw score currently obtained on this test case (considering only the last submission from each competitor). Finally, the sum of all your test scores is normalized to 100.


## Test Case Generation

Please look at the generate() method in the visualizer's source code for the exact details about test case generation. Each test case is generated as follows:

- The grid size **N** is chosen between **8** and **30**, inclusive.
- The number of queen colours **C** is chosen between **1** and **6**, inclusive.
- The wall probability **P** is chosen between **0** and **0.25**, inclusive.
- Generate the grid. Start with an empty grid. Place **N** queens of each colour at random. With probability **P** set an empty cell to be a wall. The grid generation process is repeated until there are no rows or columns containing more than **N-C** walls.
-   All values are chosen uniformly at random.


## Notes

-   In order to win a prize you must finish in the top 5 and post a description of your approach in the forums at the end of the competition.
-   Two queens located at $(r_1, c_1)$ and $(r_2, c_2)$ are on the same diagonal if $|r_1-r_2|==|c_1-c_2|$.
-   Although we reject grids with too many walls in a given row or column, it is still possible that some cases cannot be solved with a **0** *error penalty*.
-   The time limit is **10** seconds per test case (this includes only the time spent in your code). The memory limit is **1024** megabytes.
-   The compilation time limit is **30** seconds.
-   There are **10** example test cases and **100** full submission (provisional) test cases. There will be **2000** test cases in the final testing.
-   The match is rated.

## Languages Supported

C#, Java, C++ and Python

## Submission Format

Your submission must be a single ZIP file not larger than 500 MB, with your source code only. 
Please Note: Please zip only the file. Do not put it inside a folder before zipping, you should directly zip the file.

Make sure you name your Source Code file as QueenAttack*.<appropriate extension>* 

### Sample Submissions

Here are example solutions for different languages, modified to be executed with the visualizer. You may modify and submit these example solutions:

-   Java Source Code - [QueenAttack.java.zip](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/bdF1rKDxQrWNiwYBjOqV)
-   C++ Source Code - [QueenAttack.cpp.zip](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/4H3gK68VRqKoYeKGXK27)
-   Python3.6 Source Code - [QueenAttack.py.zip](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/IlngZ9ylRyGZ5exLnMQ9)
-   C# Source Code - [QueenAttack.cs.zip](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/MawPMRpqQqKTsAF8oVji)

## Tools

An offline tester is available below. You can use it to test/debug your solution locally. You can also check its source code for an exact implementation of test case generation and score calculation. You can also find links to useful information and sample solutions in several languages.

#### Downloads

- Visualizer Source - [QueenAttackTester.zip](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/Fu0MVPgQI2MGkkRTaoUR)
- Visualizer Binary - [tester.jar.zip](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/oHS0kZ0qRJSvONHjcjku)

#### Offline Tester / Visualizer

Your solution should interact with the tester/visualizer by reading data from standard input and writing data to standard output. 
  
To run the tester with your solution, you should run: 
  
**java -jar tester.jar -exec "<command>" -seed <seed>** 
  
Here, <command> is the command to execute your program, and <seed> is seed for test case generation. 
If your compiled solution is an executable file, the command will be the full path to it, for example, "C:\\TopCoder\\QueenAttack.exe" or "~/topcoder/QueenAttack". 
In case your compiled solution is to be run with the help of an interpreter, for example, if your program is in Java, the command will be something like "java -cp C:\\TopCoder QueenAttack". 
  
Additionally you can use the following options:

-   **\-seed** <seed> Sets the seed used for test case generation, default is seed 1.
-   **\-debug**. Print debug information.
-   **\-novis**. Turns off visualisation.
-   **\-noimages**. Turns off images.
-   **\-noanimate**. Turns off animation and only displays the final grid.
-   **\-showAllPaths**. Shows paths travelled by every queen.
-   **\-pause**. Starts the visualizer in paused mode. See more information below.
-   **\-delay** <delay> Sets the delay (in milliseconds) between visualizing consecutive simulation steps, default is 1000.
-   **\-manual**. Allows you to play in the manual mode. Use the left mouse click to select a queen. Click the left mouse again to move it to an empty location. Use the right mouse click to undo moves. Hover the mouse over a queen to see its path.
-   **\-N** <N> Sets a custom grid size.
-   **\-C** <C> Sets a custom number of queen colours.
-   **\-P** <P> Sets a custom wall probability.


The visualizer works in two modes. In regular mode, steps are visualized one after another with a delay specified with the -delay parameter. In paused mode, the next move will be visualized only when you press any key. The space key can be used to switch between regular and paused modes. The default starting mode is regular. You can use the -pause parameter to start in paused mode.
 
Marathon local testers have many useful options, including running a range of seeds with a single command, running more than one seed at time (multiple threads), controlling time limit, saving input/output/error and loading solution from a file. The usage of these options are described [here](https://www.topcoder.com/thrive/articles/marathon-local-tester-parameters).

Puzzle Challenge 9 | Knight Swap Discussion

description:
Welcome to Puzzle Challenge 9. This puzzle was written by **dimkadimon** and tested by **sullyper**. It can be solved by hand or with the help of a computer. You can reach out in the forums for any questions, but please do not share any ideas or solutions relating to the puzzle itself. 

## Puzzle
You are given an 8x8 grid filled with black and white chess knights as shown in the diagram. Each turn you can select a knight and move it to an empty location. As usual the knight must jump two steps in one direction and one step in an orthogonal direction. Knights can jump over other knights. Your task is to swap the location of all black and white knights in the least number of moves.

![image.png](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/7Yikgiv7Qt6a5UXoFxc5)

### Submission Guidelines
Your submission must contain a text file with the following, each on a separate line:
- **M**, the number of moves in your solution.
- **M** lines representing each move, formatted as "r1 c1 r2 c2" (without the quotes). This means that you are moving the knight from location (r1, c1) to location (r2, c2). Locations are zero based and (0, 0) is in the top-left corner.


### Judging Criteria
A solution will be considered better if it uses fewer number of moves **M**. Ties will be broken by submission time.

### Tools
We are providing a visualizer that can be used to check your solution and to play the puzzle manually:
- Visualizer source - [KnightSwapTester.zip](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/J9zzBdofT8m46sZgZB7G)
- Visualizer binary - [tester.jar.zip](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/OkUx5zRLQlea6WcLbDla)

The binary can be run with:
`java -jar tester.jar`

While the source code can be unzipped and run like so:
`javac KnightSwapTester.java`
`java KnightSwapTester`

Additionally you can use the following options:
-   **\-manual**. Allows you to play in the manual mode. Use the left mouse click to select and move knights. Use the right mouse click to undo moves. As soon as you solve the puzzle, your sequence of moves will be saved to "output.txt".
-   **\-loadSolOutput**. Load a solution file, which must be named "1.out"
-   **\-debug**. Print debug information and play a small 4x4 version of the puzzle.
-   **\-novis**. Turns off visualisation.
-   **\-pause**. Starts the visualizer in paused mode. See more information below.
-   **\-delay** <delay> Sets the delay (in milliseconds) between visualizing consecutive simulation steps, default is 1000.
-   **\-N** <N> Sets a custom grid size.

The visualizer works in two modes. In regular mode, steps are visualized one after another with a delay specified with the -delay parameter. In paused mode, the next move will be visualized only when you press any key. The space key can be used to switch between regular and paused modes. The default starting mode is regular. You can use the -pause parameter to start in paused mode.

### Challenge Schedule
This is a 7 day challenge.

name: Wealth Investment Mobile App UI Design Challenge
description:
**Round 1:**
Please submit the below screens for checkpoint
2. Overview Screen
3. Real-time Plan Value Screen
4. Summary Information Screen
5. Fund Holding Breakdown Screen

**Round 2**
1. Onboarding Screen
2. Overview Screen
3. Real-time Plan Value Screen
4. Summary Information Screen
5. Fund Holding Breakdown Screen
6. Communication Screen
7. User Management Screen


## CHALLENGE DESCRIPTION
Welcome to the Wealth Investment Mobile App UI Design Challenge. The objective of this project is to create a B2C mobile application for existing wealth investment plan holders, providing them with a secure and accessible platform to manage and view their investment plans effectively.

## CHALLENGE OBJECTIVES
-   Design UI screens for a B2C mobile application focused on wealth investment plan management.
-   Create an intuitive, user-friendly, and secure platform for plan holders.
-   Enable users to access real-time plan values, communicate securely with customer services, access plan documents only accessible via secure messaging (attachments), and manage personal details.
    

## PROJECT OVERVIEW
The mobile app is intended for existing wealth investment plan holders. Its main purpose is to offer a digital platform for customers to efficiently manage and view their investment plans, providing real-time information about their plan values, detailed plan summaries, fund holding breakdowns, secure communication with customer services, easy access to plan documents, and seamless user management. The app should support multi-language functionality in Italian, Spanish, Finnish, and Portuguese.

## USER STORY
*Below usser story gives your the overall picture on the app screens, please see the userpersonas.pdf attached in the forums to understand who will the typical users for this app.*
Meet Sam, an investor looking to manage wealth investment plans efficiently. Sam downloads the app with high expectations:

-   Sam begins with an engaging onboarding experience, discovering the app's features.
-   On the "Overview" screen, Sam views plan values, summaries, and fund holdings.
-   Sam relies on the "Real-time Plan Value" screen for up-to-the-minute plan data.
-   The "Summary Information" screen provides quick plan references.
-   Sam navigates to the "Fund Holding Breakdown" for in-depth fund insights.
-   "Communication" makes it easy to connect with the customer service team.
-   "Documentation" offers convenient access to plan documents.
-   Sam updates personal and security details on the "User Management" screen.
    
With these features, Sam manages investment plans effortlessly and makes informed financial decisions.

## AUDIENCE
-   Existing Wealth Investment Plan Holders
(Please take a look at the user_persona.pdf for more details about the typical user)
    
## SCREENS/FEATURES
Please make sure your design includes the following screens/features, also we have shared the *Website Page examples.pdf * which has information that can be used in your designs.

**1. Onboarding Screen:**
-   Engaging onboarding experience with a carousel or equivalent.
-   Showcase different app features and benefits on each screen.
-   Use visually appealing graphics and minimal, informative text.
-   Include a clear call to action (e.g. "Get Started").
-   First-time login experience (e.g. Set PIN code, Enable Biometrics, Privacy Policy acceptance, etc)
    
**-2. Overview Screen:**
- Display the current value of the user's investment plan(s).
-- Plan list where holder has 1+ plans
-- Plan summary where holder has 1 plan
- Provide a summary of each investment plan, including plan name, type, and start date.
--  Plan valuation – drill down into fund holdings
- Offer a detailed breakdown of individual fund holdings within each plan.
-- Underlying assets – drill down into EMC holdings
    
**3. Real-time Plan Value Screen:**
- Show the real-time value of the user's investment plan(s).
- Use clear visualizations like charts or graphs to illustrate the relative value of multiple plans.
- Show underlying assets under each investment plan (See PL3/4/5 View Holdings from the website page for examples)
    
**4. Summary Information Screen:**
- Present key plan information in a concise and organized format.
- Include plan names, types, start dates, and other relevant data.
- Ensure information is easily scannable for quick reference.
    
**5. Fund Holding Breakdown Screen:**
- List funds associated with each plan, including names, and percentages - time-based performance charts not required.
- Provide an intuitive navigation system for exploring fund details.
- Consider visual elements like charts or graphs for engagement.

**6. Communication Screen:**
- Create an intuitive messaging interface for seamless customer service interaction.
- Ensure organized conversations with a threaded structure for easy tracking.
- Implement real-time notifications to keep users informed.
- Enable document and image attachments for efficient communication.
 
**7. User Management Screen:**
-   Offer a user profile section for editing personal information, contact details, and preferences.
-   Include settings for security features like password changes, two-factor authentication, and notification preferences.
-   Ensure a user-friendly experience for updating information and preferences.
-   Ensure that the app supports four languages (Italian, Spanish, Finnish, and Portuguese).

##  DEVICE SPECIFICATION
Mobile Application - iOS: 1170px × 2532px

## DESIGN GOALS & PRINCIPLES
-   Design an easy-to-use and user-friendly interface.
-   Prioritize security and data privacy policy presentation being intuitive.
-   Ensure the app is accessible to users in multiple languages.
-   Create a visually appealing and engaging design.

## BRANDING GUIDELINES
Branding information is shared on the challenge discussion forum. The client is open to your typography suggestions

## JUDGMENT CRITERIA
-   Creativity: Innovative ideas and creative solutions.
-   Exploration: Flexible and adaptable design that positively impacts user goals.
-   Aesthetics: High-fidelity design with a polished visual appearance.
-   Branding: Align with provided branding guidelines and suggest improvements where appropriate.
-   NOTE: Winning participants will have to undergo BGV initiated by the client.

## MARVEL PROTOTYPE
We use Marvelapp to showcase your design to our client.
Ask for a Marvel project on the forum.
Upload your screens to Marvel, and include hotspots so that the client can see the interactions between your screens


## DESIGN ASSETS
-   Branding information/guidelines
    
## FINAL DELIVERABLES
You have to submit a single zip file that includes the following items:
Source.zip
-   All original source files.
-   Create files in Figma, Sketch, or Adobe XD.

Submission.zip
-   Your screens are exported as PNGs.
   
Declaration.txt    
-   A text file that contains all the notes about font usage, photo, and icon declarations.
-   Preview.jpg
-   Create a JPG preview file of 1024 x 1024 px.

name: Flutter Dart Fun Challenge
description:
***Flutter Dart Fun Challenge***

**Challenge Overview**

This is a fun challenge aiming to identify members for upcoming projects in this technology stack. 

**Requirements**

- Need to develop a Flutter app which supports the iOS and Android platform.
- Need to use Dart as the programming language.
- **Need to make sure that the app works correctly in both Mobile and Tablet(Portrait Mode only).**
- Best practices must be used.
- We don't have the UI design, we will be using the **Material design**. 
- Proper validations must be done.
- States should be maintained.
- A Readme.MD should be provided with the instructions on how to run the app.
- Should provide a validation video by the submitter of running the app and the screens implemented.
- Valid credentials to do the login must be documented in the Readme file.

Screens To Implement

- **Login screen**
  - Username textbox should be there.
  - Password textbox should be there with Eye icon to show/hide the typed password.
  - Sign-up button, clicking on this button will do nothing.
  - Login button, once clicked the user will be landed to the dashboard screen.
  - Required validation should be done.

- **Dashboard screen**
  - Header
    - Should have the user avatar.
    - Should have the search bar.
    - Should have the notification icon with the number of unread notification which will be static number 10, clicking on the icon will do nothing.
  - Body
    - Should have the dynamic greeting, based on the local timing Good Morning/Afternoon/Evening {{userName}}.
    - Should have one line chart of the transactions(Debit & Credit) of the user, https://pub.dev/packages/fl_chart **fl_chart** can be used for it.
    - Should have the listing of the user accounts, max 5 accounts to be shown. One user can have multiple accounts and the account types are Savings, Current, Fixed Deposit, Nominated, Personal. Need to make the data accordingly and show it in the list.
    - Above user accounts listing there will be an Add button (+ Icon), once user clicks on it the user will see a pop-up with Account type dropdown and Account number text box, the pop-up should have a Save button and once user clicks on it the Account should be added at the top in the existing accounts list. 

- **Profile screen**
  - Clicking on the user avatar in the header should navigate the user to the profile screen.
  - In the profile screen user can see the user first name, last name, phone number.
  - There should be a logout button, clicking on the button should navigate the user to the login screen.


**Judgetment Criteria**

The submissions will be subjectively reviewed by the project team. The project team will be mainly focusing on the coding standard, clean and commented code, UI implementation & functionality mentioned in the screens requirement.

discussions.name: Marathon Match 149 Discussion

description:
## Important Links

-   [Submission-Review](https://submission-review.topcoder.com/) You can find your submissions *artifacts* here. Artifacts will contain output.txt's for both example test cases and provisional test cases with stdout/stderr and individual test case scores. 
-   [Other Details](https://www.topcoder.com/thrive/articles/marathon-processor-specification-and-scoring-terminology) For other details like Processing Server Specifications, Submission Queue, Example Test Cases Execution.

## Overview

You are tasked with designing an irrigation system for a gridded garden of size **N** by **N**. The garden contains plants that need to be irrigated. Luckily a few water points are available which can be used to connect pipes and sprinklers to the irrigation system. Your design needs to provide water to as many of the plants as possible while minimising the total cost of the irrigation system.

The garden contains **S** water source cells where pipes can be connected. These pipes can only be placed in horizontal and vertical directions. Each cell containing a pipe incurs a cost of **P**. Connectors are automatically placed by the tester application wherever pipes intersect, whenever a pipe changes direction, and where pipes stop. Connecting a pipe at a water source does not use any connectors. The cost of a connector is calculated as (**C** * **X**), where **C** represents the base cost of a connector and **X** is the number of pipes attached to the connector. 

Sprinklers can be placed on top of any cell that contains a pipe, at a cost of **T**. Additionally, each sprinkler covers a radius of **Z** cells, where the cells that satisfy (**dx** * **dx** + **dy** * **dy** <= **Z** * **Z**) become irrigated by the sprinkler when water flows through it. **dx** and **dy** are the distances from the sprinkler to the plant in the horizontal and vertical directions, respectively. Any plant that was not irrigated will cost you a penalty of **N** * **N**.

Here is an example solution for seed=1. The water flow is opened after all your commands have been processed. Plants are drawn in green when they are irrigated and red when not. Black pipes indicate no water flow while pipes turn blue when the water flows through them. The cyan circles show the sprinkler placements. Water sprayed by the sprinklers can be seen in blue. The color intensity of the connectors indicates their cost. Water sources are shown as blue circles within black cells. 

![Seed1 example](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/Eubg9egNQTaIdri9niPr)

## Input and Output

Your code will receive as input the following values, each on a separate line:

-  **N**, the size of the grid.
-  **C**, the connector cost.
-  **P**, the pipe cost.
-  **T**, the sprinkler cost.
-  **Z**, the sprinkler radius.
-  **N**\***N** lines representing the grid in row-major order. Each cell is either empty (**0**), a water source (**1**) or a plant (**2**).

Your code needs to output the following:

-  The number of commands **K**.
-  **K** lines each containing a command that will build your irrigation system, you have the following two options:
   - Formatted as "P r1 c1 r2 c2" (without the quotes), where r1, c1, r2 and c2 are 0-based row and column coordinates, respectively. This will place a pipe between (r1, c1) and (r2, c2). Only horizontal or vertical pipes are allowed (r1==r2 or c1==c2).
   - Formatted as "S r c" (without the quotes), where r and c are 0-based row and column coordinates, respectively. This will place a sprinkler at cell (r, c).

## Scoring

The raw score is the cost of all the pipes, sprinklers and connectors placed plus the penalty for each plant not irrigated. If your return was invalid, then your raw score on this test case will be -1. Possible reasons include:

-   Placing a pipe on top of a plant or an already placed pipe.
-   Placing a sprinkler on top of a water source, plant or sprinkler.
-   Placing a sprinkler not on top of a pipe.
-   Placing a pipe or a sprinkler outside of the grid.
-   Exceeding the time limit.

If your raw score for a test case is negative then your normalized score for that test case is 0. Otherwise, your normalized score for each test case is MIN/YOUR, where YOUR is your raw score and MIN is the smallest positive raw score currently obtained on this test case (considering only the last submission from each competitor). Finally, the sum of all your test scores is normalized to 100.

## Test Case Generation

Please look at the generate() method in the visualizer's source code for the exact details about test case generation. Each test case is generated as follows:

- The size of the grid **N** is chosen between **8** and **50**, inclusive.
- The number of water sources **S** is chosen between **1** and **5**, inclusive.
- The cost of a connector **C** is chosen between **1** and **30**, inclusive.
- The cost of a pipe **P** is chosen between **1** and **30**, inclusive.
- The cost of a sprinkler **T** is chosen between **30** and **90**, inclusive.
- The radius of a sprinkler **Z** is chosen between **1** and **4**, inclusive.
- The plant density factor **D** is chosen between **0.05** and **0.3**, inclusive.
- Plants that can not be reached by a water pipe with a sprinker are removed from the grid by the makeValid() method.

## Notes

-   The time limit is **10** seconds per test case (this includes only the time spent in your code). The memory limit is **1024** megabytes.
-   The compilation time limit is **30** seconds.
-   There are **10** example test cases and **100** full submission (provisional) test cases. There will be **2000** test cases in the final testing.
-   The match is rated.

## Languages Supported

C#, Java, C++ and Python

## Submission Format

Your submission must be a single ZIP file not larger than 500 MB, with your source code only. 
Please Note: Please zip only the file. Do not put it inside a folder before zipping, you should directly zip the file.

Make sure you name your Source Code file as Irrigation*.<appropriate extension>* 

### Sample Submissions

Here are example solutions for different languages, modified to be executed with the visualizer. You may modify and submit these example solutions:

-   Java Source Code - [Irrigation.java.zip](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/vrFLjzhiQiQvOdTvpgJ9)
-   C++ Source Code - [Irrigation.cpp.zip](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/XuZFOHR5QBarElqVXock)
-   Python3.6 Source Code - [Irrigation.py.zip](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/7oLPknNvTNWZ5bhTawVQ)
-   C# Source Code - [Irrigation.cs.zip](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/Z0xhLhAASgySiGdiifgx)

## Tools

An offline tester is available below. You can use it to test/debug your solution locally. You can also check its source code for an exact implementation of test case generation and score calculation. You can also find links to useful information and sample solutions in several languages.

#### Downloads

- Visualizer Source - [IrrigationTester.zip](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/DGuUCKbRRby6o0UPNljE)
- Visualizer Binary - [tester.jar.zip](https://cdn.filestackcontent.com/xfiHYXuwSeOfw9Wf1JKY)

#### Offline Tester / Visualizer

Your solution should interact with the tester/visualizer by reading data from standard input and writing data to standard output. 
  
To run the tester with your solution, you should run: 
  
**java -jar tester.jar -exec "<command>" -seed <seed>** 
  
Here, <command> is the command to execute your program, and <seed> is seed for test case generation. 
If your compiled solution is an executable file, the command will be the full path to it, for example, "C:\\TopCoder\\Irrigation.exe" or "~/topcoder/Irrigation". 
In case your compiled solution is to be run with the help of an interpreter, for example, if your program is in Java, the command will be something like "java -cp C:\\TopCoder Irrigation". 
  
Additionally you can use the following options:

-   **\-seed** <seed> Sets the seed used for test case generation, default is seed 1.
-   **\-debug**. Print debug information.
-   **\-novis**. Turns off visualisation.
-   **\-pause**. Starts the visualizer in paused mode. See more information below.
-   **\-delay** <delay> Sets the delay (in milliseconds) between visualizing consecutive simulation steps, default is 1500.
-   **\-N** <N> Sets a custom grid size.
-   **\-S** <S> Sets a custom number of water sources.
-   **\-P** <P> Sets a custom pipe cost.
-   **\-C** <C> Sets a custom connector cost.
-   **\-T** <T> Sets a custom sprinkler cost.
-   **\-Z** <Z> Sets a custom sprinkler range.
-   **\-D** <D> Sets a custom plant density factor.
-   **\-showAllSteps** Visualize every command one by one.

The visualizer works in two modes. In regular mode, steps are visualized one after another with a delay specified with the -delay parameter. In paused mode, the next move will be visualized only when you press any key. The space key can be used to switch between regular and paused modes. The default starting mode is regular. You can use the -pause parameter to start in paused mode. 
 
Marathon local testers have many useful options, including running a range of seeds with a single command, running more than one seed at time (multiple threads), controlling time limit, saving input/output/error and loading solution from a file. The usage of these options are described [here](https://www.topcoder.com/thrive/articles/marathon-local-tester-parameters).
name: Marathon Match 149

description:
Welcome to Hestia DCP Frontend UI Challenge! The goal of this challenge is to update the frontend application using Angular.

Read the challenge specification carefully and watch the forums for any questions or feedback concerning this challenge. 
Let us know if you have any questions in the challenge forum!

This challenge is a part of a series of challenges with Bonus prize at the end. The bonuses will be three prizes ($1000, $500, $250) and will be decided based on the following criteria:
1. The number of challenges participated in with valid submissions
1. The number of quality submissions (one challenge, one submission, code rating)

## CHALLENGE OBJECTIVE
The scope of this challenge is to update the app with the below user stories which is [shared on the forum](https://discussions.topcoder.com/discussion/33275/assets?new=1).
1. TECS-55 (UI - Find Product By)
1. TECS-62 (UI - Product Details)
1. TECS-56 (UI - Search Results Grid View)
1. TECS-59 (UI - Search Results Thumbnail View)
1. TECS-57 (UI - Arrow Icon Button)
1. TECS-80 (UI - Product Details Not Found)
1. TECS-65 (UI - View Product By)
## TECHNOLOGY STACK
* Angular 15
* TypeScript 
* SCSS 
* HTML 5
## BROWSER REQUIREMENTS
* Windows: IE 11+, Edge, Chrome latest
* Mac: Safari Latest, Edge, Chrome Latest
* iOS Mobile & Tablet: Chrome & safari
* Android Mobile & Tablet: Chrome
## ASSETS

Submit the zip containing:

* Winner has to submit the pull request against the gitlab repo
